history.content:
Im not sure that I would recommend the combo of those three classes (but based on your previous courseloads perhaps you have the ability to do this). 

It's totally doable, but in my opinion you will definitely absorb less of each classes's material than if you could focus on just these courses. 

To compare: I took CS61c with CS70 (similar to 134) together in spring 2018 and it was hell. 61C has a massive workload, with constant lab, hw, project, and midterms, and it often overlapped with 70. The 70 psets took me a long time, even after I had taken Stat88 and Stat140 (so I was not new to probability). The entire semester was just me rushing back and forth between office hours and trying to complete assignments, and I didn't absorb much as much as the nuance of the material as I would have liked. 

I took Math110 with Stat135, Data100, and ECON101a in Fall 2018 and that course load was just at the edge of my limit - I think the only way I survived because in my Math110 semester, we didn't actually turn the homework, so there was less pressure if I couldn't figure out a problem (tho I always checked the solution when it came out). This is not true for all semesters of Math110 however. 

Math110 and Stat134 are also core classes for the track you seem to be going down, so its important to really understand all of the material and get the most out of it as possible. Math110 was one of the most valuable courses I've taken at Berkeley, and I'm using the concepts heavily in EE127 and CS189 this semester. 

So whether or not you should take this schedule depends on how you felt these past two semesters - did you feel that you could adequately absorb the material and dig deep despite your courseload? If so, then go ahead and take this courseload. 

But if you felt rushed and stressed, pick two of the three (two of them is 100% doable). 

Also you're a freshman, so you have time! Don't feel like you need to rush super fast through your courseload if you don't need to. I was pretty miserable the first two years of college because of stacking my schedule. (tho i'm still stacking it now lol I just figured out a better life balance). 

This is just my experience though and others are welcome to provide their own (possibly contrasting) opinions

EDIT: I'm happy to answer more questions about these courses if you have anything specific based on this response

I took EE16B, STAT134(adam lucas), MATH53, 61B(hug) and some breaths in a semester and it was pretty doable. STAT 134 basically takes no time and you just go to quizes and exam and that's all you need for an A after taking 70. EE16B was time consuming and 61B exam season was stressful. You should always consider 16B seriously as labs can take all your time.

Im not sure that I would recommend the combo of those three classes (but based on your previous courseloads perhaps you have the ability to do this).

children.subject: I was originally in 126 instead of the breadths this semester and it was so impossible hard lol. I feel like if I were to take it next semester there's no way I'd do well. I got an A in CS70, but even then, I felt like I was so behind on the in depth theory, and ridiculously hard applications in 126. I'm planning to use Stat 134 as a stepping stone, to sorta ease into the harder probability stuff, thoughts?

126 the first midterm theory stuff is hard / lots of tricks, but the applications and stuff later is much more approachable. 134 would let you do much better in 126 but you would also be overlapping a lot and it's kind of a waste of time imo

Assuming you did well in your first semester with CS 70 based on your schedule this semester, I'd strongly recommend to take EECS 126 instead of Stat 134. 126 covers probability in more depth and taking it will also benefit other courses such as 189.
and slightly more difficult than first semester

Hmmm that's good to hear, but I don't think it's slightly harder than first semester, my current load is killing me :'(. I found first semester pretty chill (I joined my breadths late and missed a week of school early on though).
sorry i meant to say 61c, Math 110, and Stat 134 would be slightly more difficult than first semester.
Your current workload is higher than 61c, Math 110, and Stat 134.

This is just a personal opinion but maybe take classes that build on top of each other in a way that allows you to draw from previous semesters' concepts and ideas so you begin seeing the beauty in the applied and theory of cs. 

I've take EE16A, CS 61 series, and currently, in EE 16B, Stat 134 and Math 53, planning to take 70 in the summer. I eventually plan to take EE 126/127, CS 189, and SWE classes(170, 186, and 162)

I would highly recommend having one theoretical and one applied every semester. Specifically, taking EE 16A(or some other class since you've already taken it) with CS 61B, CS 61C with possibly 70 or a stats, then EE 16B with Math 53.

I found transitioning from 61B to 61C really nice because in a very very simplified way teaches you the beauty of turning python code into the 1s and 0s in your computer and how the thing actually works with your computer's clock cycles(there's also a bit of parallelism and warehouse-scale computing). Following that, 16B was redesigned this semester to go even lower level than the transistors and circuitry to the atomic/molecular level of what current actually is in terms of the electrons flowing around PMOS's and NMOS's so I found it amazingly neat to see python code from 61A become more efficient through 61B, and code compiling from 61B get translated to 1s and 0s, which are then "represented" with voltages in circuits and electrons flowing through transistors. Additionally, taking Math 53 has minimal overlap with EE16B since 16B uses imaginary numbers which is the same as having a third dimension, along with having differential equations. 

That's just what I've taken so far, but it really excites me for the upper division classes specifically in OS's, ML, Computer Security, and efficient algorithms. I just find it more logical and interesting to go through classes this way. It becomes more like a CS discovery path than "school and classes"

history.content:
I'm currently a freshmen and the midterm anxiety makes me wanna start planning for next semester in hopes that it's easier. I would love to hear everyone's opinion on this course load and how it compares to my other semesters!

Semester 1: 

CS70 

CS61A

EE16A

Semester 2: 

CS170 

CS61B

EE16B

8 Units of Breadths (all PNP)

Intended Semester 3: 

- CS61C

- Stat 134 

- Math 110 

For people who have taken these courses before, what are your thoughts on this workload? Ideally, it's significantly easier than my current semester (around first semester difficulty or easier would be ideal).
history.subject: CS61C, Stat 134, Math 110 Course Load
